KPBB Desak Pemerintah Hentikan Peleburan Aki Bekas Ilegal
02 Nov 2019, 10:10 by Tempo.co, Erwin Prima
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Direktur Komite Penghapusan Bensin Bertimbal (KPBB) Ahmad Safrudin mendesak pemerintah untuk menghentikan praktik peleburan aki bekas ilegal serta menghukum para pelakunya.
Ahmad menyebutkan bahwa desakan ini muncul mengingat sudah banyak korban yang terdampak oleh usaha ilegal ini. Penelitian KPBB mencatat bahwa ada 21 anak-anak di Cinangka, Kabupaten Bogor, yang terdampak akibat peleburan aki bekas ilegal ini. Menurut Ahmad, anak-anak itu di antaranya mengidap wrist drop, foot drop, hingga kejang-kejang.
"Padahal Konstitusi kita pasal 28H kan sudah menjamin bahwa setiap orang berhak hidup sejahtera lahir dan batin, bertempat tinggal dan mendapalkan lingkungan hidup yang baik dan sehat," ungkap Ahmad di Jakarta, Jumat 1 November 2019.
Sebelumnya, Ahmad memaparkan bahwa kawasan Jakarta, Bogor, Depok, Tangerang, dan Bekasi (Jabodetabek) ini ada 71 titik yang teridentifikasi sebagai tempat peleburan aki bekas ilegal. Tak hanya itu, Koordinator Program KPBB Alfred Sitorus juga mengungkapkan usaha ilegal ini juga sudah merambah hingga ke wilayah seperti Tegal, Pasuruan, Lamongan, Sidoarjo, Medan, hingga Lampung.
"Di Lamongan sendiri ada sekitar 30 tempat peleburan aki bekas ilegal. Untuk Pasuruan sekitar 10, Sidoarji ada 5 tempat, bahkan di Tegal arah Klaten ada sekitar 50 tempat," ujar Alfred pada kesempatan yang sama.
"Oleh karena itu pemerintah harus segera menghentikan dan menghukum pelakunya sesuai dengan UU Nomor 32 Tahun 2009 tentang Perlindungan dan Pengelolaan Lingkungan Hidup dan dan PP Nomor 101 Tahun 2014 tentang Pengelolaan Limbah B3," imbuhnya.
Lebih jauh lagi, Alfred menegaskan bahwa bila pemerintah tidak melakukan sesuai amanat konstitusi maupun peraturan yang berlaku, tak menutup kemungkinan bahwa masyarakat sipil akan menggugat pemerintah ke pengadilan.
"Ini kan artinya pemerintah melakukan pembiaran atas terjadinya pencemaran yang secara kronis telah berdampak pada jatuhnya korban menderita sakit bahkan berujung kematian," lanjutnya.
Ahmad mengakui bahwa aki bekas merupakan komoditas yang seksi. Namun di sisi lain, usaha peleburan aki bekas ilegal ini juga mendatangkan bahaya kronis dari segi lingkungan dan kesehatan.
"Makanya, pemerintah perlu skema dan pengawasan yang secara ketat mengatur itu. Misalnya dengan ketentuan bahwa aki bekas yang ada di pasaran harus ditarik kembali oleh produsennya atau dengan skema collecting point (pengumpul) resmi," ujarnya.
Selain membuat ketentuan yang jelas, KPBB juga meminta pemerintah untuk melakukan pembinaan terhadap peleburan aki bekas yang resmi. "Agar sirkular ekonomi pengelolaan aki bekas berjalan baik, efektif, serta tidak merusak lingkungan," ujar Ahmad.

KPBB Urges the Government to Stop Smelting Illegal Batteries
02 Nov 2019, 10:10 by Tempo.co, Erwin Prima
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Director of the Committee for the Elimination of Leaded Gasoline (KPBB) Ahmad Safrudin urged the government to stop the practice of fusing used illegal batteries and punish the perpetrators.
Ahmad said that this pressure arises considering that many victims have been affected by this illegal business. The KPBB study noted that there were 21 children in Cinangka, Bogor Regency, who were affected by the fusion of this illegal used battery. According to Ahmad, some of them had wrist drop, foot drop, and convulsions.
"Whereas our Article 28H constitution already guarantees that everyone has the right to live in physical and spiritual prosperity, to live and obtain a good and healthy environment," Ahmad said in Jakarta, Friday, November 1, 2019.
Previously, Ahmad explained that the Jakarta, Bogor, Depok, Tangerang and Bekasi (Jabodetabek) areas had 71 points which were identified as illegal smelting of used batteries. Not only that, KPBB Program Coordinator Alfred Sitorus also revealed that this illegal business has also expanded to areas such as Tegal, Pasuruan, Lamongan, Sidoarjo, Medan, and Lampung.
"In Lamongan alone there are about 30 places where illegal smelting is used. For Pasuruan there are about 10, Sidoarji there are 5 places, even in Tegal in the direction of Klaten there are about 50 places," Alfred said on the same occasion.
"Therefore, the government must immediately stop and punish the perpetrators in accordance with Law Number 32 Year 2009 concerning Environmental Protection and Management and PP No. 101 of 2014 concerning B3 Waste Management," he added.
Furthermore, Alfred asserted that if the government did not comply with the mandate of the constitution or regulations, it did not rule out the possibility that civil society would take the government to court.
"This means that the government has allowed the occurrence of pollution that has chronically affected the fall of victims suffering from illness or even death," he continued.
Ahmad admitted that used batteries are a sexy commodity. But on the other hand, this illegal used battery smelting business also poses chronic dangers in terms of the environment and health.
"Therefore, the government needs a scheme and supervision that strictly regulates it. For example, with the provision that the used batteries on the market must be withdrawn by the manufacturer or by an official collecting point (collector) scheme," he said.
In addition to making clear provisions, the KPBB also asked the government to provide guidance on the official merging of used batteries. "So that the circular economy of used battery management runs well, effectively and does not damage the environment," Ahmad said.
